item.title: Natural Deduction with Derived Rules Answers
item.description: A sheet of proof-solutions for the exercise on TFL natural deduction with derived rules are → here. One important caveat: these are only the solutions I happened to see first, and which seemed to me at least as efficient as other solutions I immediately saw. There are always many other solutions, and especially many other legitimate ways of ordering inferences. So, your answer that’s quite unlike what I’ve done isn’t necessarily wrong!

item.title: FOL Parentheses
item.description: The following specifies where, for your work in this course, parentheses are and are not optional in First Order Logic: Textbook Section 26.4 allows us to omit the outermost brackets of any formula (so, “P⋁Q” is just as good as “(P⋁Q)”). And it allows square brackets (“[” and “]”) in place of parentheses wherever we feel it increases readability. Our textbook generally does not put parentheses around quantifiers, like ∀x and ∃x.

item.title: Variant Rule Names
item.description: In the Basic deduction rules for TFL (summarized in textbook Appendix C, section 3.4), the names of the negation rules are a little confusing. I’m not the first instructor using this textbok to point this out. So, I offer you the following alternatives. In a natural deduction proof, in your justification column, you may optionally invoke the contradiction rule (¬E) by writing “contradiction” or “contra.” instead; because ¬I and IP are symmetrical rules1, but not named symmetrically, you may optionally invoke ¬I by calling it “IP” In other words, I won’t mark those two alternatives wrong on homework or tests.

item.title: Test 2
item.description: Test 2, administered at class time on December 2, may include the following: Offer the definition of “logically valid.” Answer true-false questions using the terms/concepts from the [vocabulary][vocabulary] sheet, very similar to the true-false exercises you’ve done. Given a logically valid argument expressed in English, construct a symbolization key for the atomic sentences and/or names and predicates within them, in a way that’s adequate to bring out the logical validity of the argument.

item.title: Test 1
item.description: Test 1, at class time on October 12, may include the following tasks: Define “logically valid.” Answer true-false questions using the terms/concepts from the vocabulary sheet, very similar to the true-false exercises you’ve done. Look at a few sentences, and construct a symbolization key for the atomic propositions in those sentences—one adequate to bring out their truth-functional structure. Using a symbolization key, symbolize English sentences in TFL. Using a symbolization key, translate symbolized TFL sentences into English.

item.description: These are technical words we have learned so far. Generally, you can find these words in the forall x book highlighted in pink small-caps. A student asked for a compiled list of them, for the purpose of making flash cards.
